original.definition: take a court case to a higher court for review

sememes.reasoning: The verb describes initiating a formal legal process to modify the standing or jurisdiction of a court case, thus changing its legal status.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who actively initiates the appeal, as indicated by the verb frame.
The 'court case' (from the definition) that undergoes a change in its legal status and is submitted for review.
The 'higher court' (from the definition) to which the case is directed for further legal process.

Evidentiality.reasoning: A legal appeal is a formal, documented process, generally treated as direct experience within the legal context.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating a legal action.

Modality.reasoning: The 'Somebody' in the frame implies an agent acting with strong will and intention in initiating a legal appeal.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of appealing itself is a neutral legal procedure; its context or outcome may carry sentiment, but the verb does not inherently.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody ----s' explicitly indicates a volitional agent performing the deliberate act of appealing.

Confidence.reasoning: The act of appealing is described as a definite legal occurrence.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme refers to a single, discrete instance of initiating an appeal, although a person may appeal multiple times.

participants.reasoning: value_type 'court_case.n.01' is not a valid synset in NLTK.

candidates.description: (law) the act of remitting (especially the referral of a law case to another court) (gloss match)
the number of cases handled in a given period of time (as by a court or agency) (gloss match)
a judgment disposing of the case before the court; after the judgment (or an appeal from it) is rendered all that remains is to enforce the judgment (gloss match)
(law) a railing that encloses the part of the courtroom where the judges and lawyers sit and the case is tried (gloss match)
a concluding summary (as in presenting a case before a law court) (gloss match)
(law) the calendar of a court; the list of cases to be tried or a summary of the court's activities (gloss match)
a list or register of events (appointments or social events or court cases etc) (gloss match)
an opinion that agrees with the court's disposition of the case but is written to express a particular judge's reasoning (gloss match)
an opinion that disagrees with the court's disposition of the case (gloss match)
a common law writ issued by a superior court to one of inferior jurisdiction demanding the record of a particular case (gloss match)
a judicial writ from a higher court ordering a lower court not to exercise jurisdiction in a particular case (gloss match)
a court having jurisdiction over criminal cases (gloss match)
a mock court where law students argue hypothetical cases (gloss match)
(Roman Catholic Church) the supreme ecclesiastical tribunal for cases appealed to the Holy See from diocesan courts (gloss match)
the first court before which the facts of a case are decided (gloss match)
a lawyer who pleads cases in court (gloss match)
an adviser to the court on some matter of law who is not a party to the case; usually someone who wants to influence the outcome of a lawsuit involving matters of wide public interest (gloss match)
an attorney appointed by a court to investigate and report on a case (gloss match)

participants.corrected_reasoning: LLM suggestion: 'lawsuit.n.01' is a perfect semantic match for 'court case' in the context of an appeal.
